text.p: Tunisia, which started harvesting this week, said on Friday it expected a "moderate" cereals crop this season.
"Production will be moderate because of an important rains deficit in the production areas, but it will be satisfactory regarding quality," Agriculture Minister Mabrouk Bahri told reporters.

Bahri declined to give any figures. Traders told Reuters that to meet domestic consumption needs estimated at nearly two million tonnes, Tunisia's imports of cereals would cost about 230 million dinars by the end of 1997.

Tunisia has halved the area sown to cereals this season because of low rainfall, mainly in central and southern regions. Total area sown was one million hectares (784,000 hectares of that in the northern region) from the two million ha total the previous season.
Cereals output in 1996 reached 2.63 million tonnes and averaged 1.607 million tonnes yearly during the last five years. ($= 1.1016 dinar)
